author: iPadBorked (invalid@example.com)
title: I changed my iPad Pro's wallpaper and now full screen apps (particularly games) are entirely unusable and crash and restart my device
text:
Hi. I am having a major device-breaking issue with my iPad Pro which is rendering me unable to use certain applications that I commonly use on my device. Every time I load certain full screen applications, my iPad Pro crashes and restarts after a period of time, typically a few seconds to a few minutes.
Device: iPad Pro, 11-inch, 2nd generation, 128GB & Wi-Fi only model ( iPad Pro 11-inch (2nd generation) - Technical Specifications - Apple Support )
iPad OS Version: 17.6.1
Steps I did that led up to this issue:
I recently updated from an older version of iPadOS to version 17. After updating my device, I noticed that loading & using many full screen applications for a period of time would cause my device's wallpaper to disappear and turn black on both the home screen and lock screen. Restarting my device would restore my wallpaper. This issue most commonly occurred with full screen apps like games, such as Genshin Impact or Honkai: Star Rail, but I've also had this issue with art applications like Procreate. I decided to change my device's wallpaper to see if it would fix the issue of my wallpaper disappearing. This seems to have made the issue worse. Now when I load those same full screen applications that previously caused my wallpaper to disappear after a period of time, my device instead crashes and restarts after a short period of time, typically a few seconds to a few minutes.
Notes:
Reducing the graphics settings in Honkai: Star Rail and Genshin Impact from High to Low seems to reduce the frequency of my device crashing and restarting. As said though, it doesn't fix the issue, simply reduces its frequency. I don't know for sure if the wallpaper issue is related or entirely a coincidence, but I find it weird that the initial strange behaviour with full screen apps messed with my device's wallpaper and then the crashes began the moment I changed my device's wallpaper.
This issue has rendered me entirely unable to use most full screen applications on my device and has effectively rendered my iPad unusable to me as I originally bought this device with doing both professional art production and being able to play mobile games in mind. I can't do either if my device crashes repeatedly when I try to do said tasks on it.
Any help would be extremely appreciated.

title: Trump autorizou opera√ß√£o secreta da CIA nas redes sociais chinesas - Atualidade - SAPO 24
text:
A not√≠cia esta a ser avan√ßada esta quinta-feira pela Reuters , que escreve que Trump estava h√° dois anos em fun√ß√µes como Presidente dos Estados Unidos quando autorizou esta opera√ß√£o secreta da CIA.
Segundo ex-oficiais com conhecimento direto desta opera√ß√£o, o objetivo era usar as redes sociais para influenciar a opini√£o p√∫blica chinesa contra o seu governo de Xi Jinping.
Esta opera√ß√£o foi realizada por uma pequena equipa de operacionais que usaram identidades falsas para espalhar narrativas nas redes sociais chinesas contra o governo de Xi Jinping. Ao mesmo tempo, divulgavam informa√ß√µes depreciativas a meios de comunica√ß√£o social estrangeiros.
A opera√ß√£o teve in√≠cio em 2019 e n√£o tinha sido do conhecimento p√∫blico at√© hoje.
A equipa da CIA respons√°vel por esta opera√ß√£o promoveu alega√ß√µes de que membros do Partido Comunista chin√™s em fun√ß√µes esconderam dinheiro il√≠cito no estrangeiro, al√©m de criticarem duramente a iniciativa chinesa Rota da Seda, que visa aumentar a influ√™ncia da China atrav√©s do financiamento de infra-estruturas pelo mundo, sobretudo nos pa√≠ses em desenvolvimento.
As autoridades norte-americanas recusaram fornecer detalhes, mas garantem que as informa√ß√µes depreciativas veiculadas eram baseadas em factos. N√£o s√£o claras as consequ√™ncias desta opera√ß√£o secreta conduzida em 2019 e a porta-voz de Biden no Conselho Nacional de Seguran√ßa, Kate Waters, recusou esclarecer se o programa ainda se mant√©m ativo.
Porque o seu tempo √© precioso. Subscreva a newsletter do SAPO 24.

author: yahoo
title: Trump trial updates: David Pecker testifies about election-year hush money payments to Stormy Daniels, Karen McDougal
text:
Yahoo News Trump trial updates: David Pecker testifies about election-year hush money payments to Stormy Daniels, Karen McDougal David Knowles ¬∑ Senior Editor Updated April 26, 2024 at 12:57 AM ¬∑ 4 min read 7.9k Former President Donald Trump. (Mark Peterson/Pool/AFP via Getty Images)
Oops! Something went wrong. Please try again later. More content below Oops! Something went wrong. Please try again later. More content below Oops! Something went wrong. Please try again later. More content below Oops! Something went wrong. Please try again later. More content below
The former publisher of the National Enquirer told a jury about negotiations in 2016 with two women looking to sell their stories about alleged sexual relationships with then presidential candidate Donald Trump . This is Yahoo News' succinct update on the criminal and civil cases against Trump. Here are the latest developments.
üö® What happened today Former National Enquirer publisher David Pecker resumed his testimony Thursday in Trump‚Äôs trial on 34 felony counts of falsifying business records. He detailed hush money payment negotiations with adult film actress Stormy Daniels and former Playboy model Karen McDougal, both of whom sought to sell their stories alleging an extramarital affair with Trump. During questioning by prosecutors, Pecker said he had sought to promote Trump‚Äôs candidacy in 2016 despite knowing that such an arrangement violated campaign finance laws. During cross-examination, Trump‚Äôs lawyers portrayed those efforts as ‚Äústandard operating procedure.‚Äù
üìå Tell me more Payment to McDougal: Pecker testified about the $150,000 contract McDougal signed with the Enquirer for the exclusive rights to her story about a sexual affair with Trump. The contract, which was signed three months before the 2016 presidential election, stemmed from the deal Pecker reached with Trump in 2015 to promote his presidential candidacy. Pecker testified that he knew the deal was illegal, made it anyway in order to protect Trump and later lied about doing so. Pecker described asking Trump lawyer Michael Cohen who would pay the contract fee to McDougal. He said Cohen responded, ‚ÄúThe boss will take care of it,‚Äù in reference to Trump. Later, however, he said Cohen told him that the magazine should pay. Pecker said the Enquirer disguised the payment as a fee for McDougal‚Äôs services to the magazine to avoid breaking campaign finance laws. During a 2017 meeting with Trump, Pecker said, the president-elect asked him, ‚ÄúHow‚Äôs our girl doing?‚Äù He then thanked him for ‚Äúhandling the McDougal situation.‚Äù During a second meeting at the White House in July 2017, Trump asked, ‚ÄúHow is Karen doing?‚Äù Pecker testified.
Payment to Daniels: Pecker testified that after he had already paid McDougal $150,000 and former Trump Tower doorman Dino Sajudin $30,000 to bury a later debunked story about Trump fathering a child out of wedlock, he refused to pay Daniels $120,000 in October of 2016 for the exclusive rights to her story about an alleged affair with Trump. He said he told Cohen that he should pay her if he wanted to keep it from going public. ‚ÄúI am not going to be involved with a porn star,‚Äù Pecker said he told Cohen, adding that if Cohen didn‚Äôt pay Daniels to keep quiet and the story was published elsewhere, ‚ÄúI believe the boss is going to be very angry with you.‚Äù Cohen ended up paying Daniels $130,000 for her silence, and she signed a nondisclosure agreement. After Daniels gave an interview on CNN, Trump told Pecker that she had violated the agreement and owed him $24 million, Pecker testified. Prosecutors allege that the payments to McDougal and Daniels were made as part of a conspiracy to promote Trump‚Äôs 2016 presidential campaign and were in violation of campaign finance laws. In 2018, the Federal Election Commission sent letters to Cohen and Pecker asking for information. ‚ÄúWe committed a campaign violation,‚Äù Pecker said he told Cohen, who reportedly responded, ‚ÄúJeff Sessions is the attorney general and Donald Trump has him in his pocket.‚Äù After leaving the National Enquirer‚Äôs parent company, Pecker signed a cooperation agreement with the Manhattan district attorney‚Äôs office that spares him from being prosecuted in this case.
Cross-examination of Pecker: Defense lawyer Emil Bove sought to show that the National Enquirer‚Äôs deal with Trump to purchase and bury negative stories was ‚Äústandard operating procedure‚Äù for a tabloid newspaper. Pecker testified that the Enquirer had also suppressed stories for former California Gov. Arnold Schwarzenegger, actor Mark Wahlberg and former Chicago Mayor Rahm Emanuel. He told the jury that he had informed Trump about negative stories prior to Trump‚Äôs decision to run for president in 2016, and that another reason the Enquirer refrained from publishing negative stories about Trump was that doing so was good for business.
Meanwhile: As Trump listened to Pecker‚Äôs testimony, Judge Lewis Kaplan, who oversaw E. Jean Carroll‚Äôs civil trial against Trump, denied a motion to overturn the $83.3 million judgment in that case and grant him a new trial. In Washington, Trump‚Äôs lawyers argued before the Supreme Court that presidential immunity protects him from being prosecuted for his efforts to overturn the results of the 2020 election.
üóì What‚Äôs next? Trump‚Äôs lawyers will continue their cross-examination of Pecker on Friday. Court will resume at 9:30 a.m. ET.
üìñ The background ‚öñÔ∏è Trump‚Äôs trials and legal cases View comments
